s.text: In the Nov. 20 "Give It Back to the Injuns," an unbalanced and frothing David Plotz refers to Oklahoma Republicans as "a top to bottom roster of kooks, losers, and terrors."
I live in Tulsa, Okla., and your story "Give It Back to the Injuns" hit the nail right on the head.
I live in Tulsa, Okla., and your story "Give It Back to the Injuns" hit the nail right on the head.
As always, though, great column, despite our difference of opinion in sexual politics.
As always, though, great column, despite our difference of opinion in sexual politics.
As always, though, great column, despite our difference of opinion in sexual politics.
As always, though, great column, despite our difference of opinion in sexual politics.
That tone goes over better for chiding the guy who forgot to bring the beer to Sunday football.
That tone goes over better for chiding the guy who forgot to bring the beer to Sunday football.

Since court findings of paternity cost the imputed fathers eighteen years' worth of support, it seems only fair that women be held accountable for any promises they make about attempting to remain childless.

Since court findings of paternity cost the imputed fathers eighteen years' worth of support, it seems only fair that women be held accountable for any promises they make about attempting to remain childless.

Re the extraordinary and articulate article "Give It Back to the Injuns": If only we Oklahomans were less genially mediocre, we'd probably be more appreciative of your ability to slap the faces of so many different groups of Oklahomans all at the same time and in such a charming way.

Re the extraordinary and articulate article "Give It Back to the Injuns": If only we Oklahomans were less genially mediocre, we'd probably be more appreciative of your ability to slap the faces of so many different groups of Oklahomans all at the same time and in such a charming way.

But, as it is, you come off as just another self-appointed jerk who appears to write articles mainly for the pleasure of seeing his name and opinions in print, instead of being a person who uses words to persuade rather than to malign.

In the absence of that, a woman's promise to take charge of birth control and then not doing so remains the only form of monetary fraud Today's Papers can think of that is not only not punished, but is in fact regularly rewarded.
